Mr. **NAME[AAA] is a **AGE[in 40s]- year-old male with quadriplegia secondary to C4 - C5 injury after a fall 20 years ago .
The patient was admitted to the hospital through the ER with complaints of significant hematuria .
He is 5 days status post cystoscopy and sphincterotomy by Dr. **NAME[ZZZ] .
The patient was subsequently found to have an intraperitoneal bladder perforation upon workup and was therefore taken to the operating room on **DATE[Sep 22 2007] , by Dr. **NAME[ZZZ] , whereby he underwent an open repair of his intraperitoneal bladder perforation .
The procedure was uncomplicated .
The patient 's postoperative course was also fairly uncomplicated .
After a few days ' stay in the intensive care unit , the patient was brought to the floor .
By **DATE[Sep 27 2007] , the patient was tolerating a regular diet , had return of bowel function , and pain was under control .
His urine remained clear .
He was therefore deemed stable for discharge back to home and he is told he may resume a regular diet as tolerated .
No heavy lifting or strenuous exercise for 6 weeks , although the patient is fairly immobile secondary to his quadriplegia .
The patient may shower but no tub bath for 1 to 2 weeks .
The patient will follow up with Dr. **NAME[ZZZ] in approximately 2 weeks at **PHONE , and will call for an appointment .
The patient was told to resume all home medications .
